ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Much stronger command of Hebrew.
Breadth of topics at intersection of Arabic and Israeli culture.

In this course, my Hebrew abilities greatly improved in all areas: speaking, writing, reading, and listening. I also learned a lot about the interaction between Hebrew and Arabic, as well as the two cultures.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Incredibly well structured  best L5 Hebrew class out there.

This course was very well-organized to support student learning. I enjoyed the small class size and appreciated meeting only once a week to help with zoom fatigue. Another strength of the course was the feedback, real-time feedback while speaking in class as well as turning in multiple drafts for large writing assignments and correcting our homework mistakes. I especially enjoyed that we incorporated our mistakes into our quizzes, which made them more useful and less arbitrary. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Padlet >>> Canvas. Incredible tool to facilitate changes to syllabus without causing confusing / stress. Hope its here to stay.
Padlet was amazing to visualize our work and class topics. I also loved the collaborative google docs.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Absolutely. Best L5 Hebrew course on offer. The class in very well structured. The topics are interesting and engaging  both in context of homework and class discussion. I got so much better at Hebrew its crazy.
Dina is a fantastic instructor. If you are looking for an L5 Hebrew course, pick this.
Definitely. This is the L5 course to take if you want to reach a new level of Hebrew.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We used Padlet instead of Canvas to upload assignments and organize homework/topics for the week. We used collaborative google docs to receive feedback on homework and major writing assignments.
